[{'created': '2021-03-23 10:05:49.000000000', 'message': "Ensure we get the relevant fcontext overrides

Until now, running a restorecon could break the SELinux labels. In order
to avoid such an issue, we can override the existing rules pushed in
/etc/selinux/targeted/contexts/ using fcontext. It makes the change
persistent across reboots.

Please note the following:
- sefcontext triggers a policy reload
- fcontext doesn't actually apply the labels
- creating the fcontext entry before creating the file allows to get the
  file created with the right labels directly

commit_message:
Ensure we get the relevant fcontext overrides

Until now, running a restorecon could break the SELinux labels. In order
to avoid such an issue, we can override the existing rules pushed in
/etc/selinux/targeted/contexts/ using fcontext. It makes the change
persistent across reboots.

Please note the following:
- sefcontext triggers a policy reload
- fcontext doesn't actually apply the labels
- creating the fcontext entry before creating the file allows to get the
  file created with the right labels directly
- we have to ensure SELinux is enabled on the host before actually
  creating the rules.

Change-Id: I6ce262a6e77a4d40b6ff246240d21390289cc54b

commit_message:
Set config_heat_extra_yaml before building converge script.

The converge script requires from the parameter config_heat_extra_yaml
to be set before we build the script, otherwise it won't add the
config_heat_extra.yaml file in the converge command.

This patch modifies the order, so common/build_extra_template.yaml is
executed before creating the script.

Change-Id: I31d6228720248908a66e05d5c145bad6a2c85312

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-03 17:01:39.000000000', 'message': 'volume: Add 'volume group *' commands

These mirror the 'cinder group-*' commands, with arguments copied across
essentially verbatim. The only significant departures are the
replacement of "tenant" terminology with "project" and the merging of
the various volume group replication action commands into the parent
volume group (e.g. 'openstack volume group set --enable-replication'
instead of 'cinder group enable-replication')

  volume group create
  volume group delete
  volume group list
  volume group show
  volume group set
  volume group failover

Change-Id: I3b2c0cb92b8a53cc1c0cefa3313b80f59c9e5835
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
volume: Add 'volume group *' commands

These mirror the 'cinder group-*' commands, with arguments copied across
essentially verbatim. The only significant departures are the
replacement of "tenant" terminology with "project" and the merging of
the various volume group replication action commands into the parent
volume group (e.g. 'openstack volume group set --enable-replication'
instead of 'cinder group enable-replication')

  volume group create
  volume group delete
  volume group list
  volume group show
  volume group set
  volume group failover

Change-Id: I3b2c0cb92b8a53cc1c0cefa3313b80f59c9e5835
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

subject: Fix VALIDATIONS_LOG_BASEDIR constant when $HOME is undefined
messages: [{'account_id': 27329, 'date': '2021-06-18 09:00:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11491, 'date': '2021-06-18 09:22:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 32926, 'date': '2021-06-18 09:25:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 16515, 'date': '2021-06-18 10:40:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2\n\nThanks'}, {'account_id': 27427, 'date': '2021-06-18 12:33:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-18 09:00:20.000000000', 'message': "Fix VALIDATIONS_LOG_BASEDIR constant when $HOME is undefined

When $HOME environment variable is not defined below definition
raises TypeError:

  VALIDATIONS_LOG_BASEDIR = os.path.join(os.environ.get('HOME'), 'validations')

This replaces it by using os.path.expanduser[1] function

  VALIDATIONS_LOG_BASEDIR = os.path.expanduser('~/validations')

This issue has been detected by Tobiko CI jobs [2]:

 validations_libs/constants.py:25: in <module>
    VALIDATIONS_LOG_BASEDIR = os.path.join(os.environ.get('HOME'), 'validations')
 posixpath.py:76: in join
    a = os.fspath(a)
E   TypeError: expected str, bytes or os.PathLike object, not NoneType

[1] https://docs.python.org/3.6/library/os.path.html#os.path.expanduser
[2] https://813cfae3a1563ccfbfb3-c77d7211b8c124ad183202888cc1ebe6.ssl.cf5.rackcdn.com/796831/4/check/devstack-tobiko-gate/67bcea8/tobiko_results_04_faults_faults.html

Change-Id: I13ba1b2eb0b11c2aded35b44c7fbae643210a269
"}]
commit_message:
Fix VALIDATIONS_LOG_BASEDIR constant when $HOME is undefined

When $HOME environment variable is not defined below definition
raises TypeError:

  VALIDATIONS_LOG_BASEDIR = os.path.join(os.environ.get('HOME'), 'validations')

This replaces it by using os.path.expanduser[1] function

  VALIDATIONS_LOG_BASEDIR = os.path.expanduser('~/validations')

This issue has been detected by Tobiko CI jobs [2]:

 validations_libs/constants.py:25: in <module>
    VALIDATIONS_LOG_BASEDIR = os.path.join(os.environ.get('HOME'), 'validations')
 posixpath.py:76: in join
    a = os.fspath(a)
E   TypeError: expected str, bytes or os.PathLike object, not NoneType

[1] https://docs.python.org/3.6/library/os.path.html#os.path.expanduser
[2] https://813cfae3a1563ccfbfb3-c77d7211b8c124ad183202888cc1ebe6.ssl.cf5.rackcdn.com/796831/4/check/devstack-tobiko-gate/67bcea8/tobiko_results_04_faults_faults.html

Change-Id: I13ba1b2eb0b11c2aded35b44c7fbae643210a269

commit_message:
Add support for OVS DPDK pmd auto balance parameters.

This patch adds 3 new role specific THT parameters to configure OVS DPDK
pmd auto balance feature, OvsPmdLoadThreshold (PMD load threshold)
OvsPmdImprovementThreshold (variance in PMD improvement threshold)
OvsPmdRebalInterval (minimum time between 2 consecutive
PMD auto load balancing iterations).

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/790251
Signed-off-by: yogananth subramanian <ysubrama@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Id74ba956cf29241c93849602ab05c21c1ccb2b06

commit_message:
Refresh instance after adding allocation

When the baremetal deployment workflow does the
"Check Existing" task it will create a baremetal
allocation for provisioned nodes that does not
already hae one.

After creating the allocation, refresh the instance
to ensure the hostname is correctly represented in
the object returned in the list of "found" nodes.

Closes-Bug: #1929555
Change-Id: I0d43f42c0d0b092218f78b32ac3bfd198c988de0
(cherry picked from commit f661f34c90b747772219f8a68a65128dafe871e1)

commit_message:
default to max version when no session

This change fixes a regresssion intoduced
by the supprot for microverion auto-negotiation
which resulted in the inablity to generate
bash autocompltion.

When the client_manager does not have a api session established
such as when being invoked for auto completion this
change modifies get_version to return version.MAX_VERSION_NO_GAP

Story: #2008958
Task: #42592
Change-Id: I90e1e3caeaa22ff51df515226b3ac5c7b64c88b6

'}, {'created': '2021-04-13 09:53:15.000000000', 'message': 'OVN DBs clustering

We introduce support for running both the NB and SB OVN databases in
clustered mode. This OVN DBs clustered mode is based on OVNs own
clustering protocol and does not rely on pacemaker.

Clustering the two OVN databases increases reliability. The cluster
works in active-active mode and has the potential to be more
resilient and performant.

See
https://docs.openvswitch.org/en/latest/ref/ovsdb.7/#clustered-database-service-model
for more information.

Co-Authored-By: Michele Baldessari <michele@acksyn.org>

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/776969

commit_message:
OVN DBs clustering

We introduce support for running both the NB and SB OVN databases in
clustered mode. This OVN DBs clustered mode is based on OVNs own
clustering protocol and does not rely on pacemaker.

Clustering the two OVN databases increases reliability. The cluster
works in active-active mode and has the potential to be more
resilient and performant.

See
https://docs.openvswitch.org/en/latest/ref/ovsdb.7/#clustered-database-service-model
for more information.

Co-Authored-By: Michele Baldessari <michele@acksyn.org>

Related-Bug: #1931133
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/776969
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/puppet-tripleo/+/795155

Change-Id: I59bfe69dbb5f3d525ac6f6d655577d24036328c0

subject: Add ovn clustering support

commit_message:
Add ovn clustering support

This patch will add ovn clustering support, Basically it will use first
node to start cluster and then new nodes will use leader node to join
cluster.

Change-Id: I4b11d3484c99e538ecd6f7d05570486b5f59c782

Add a couple of missing options to each command:

  volume backup create
    --no-incremental
    --property
    --availability-zone

  volume backup set
    --property

Most of these are version dependent so we add the relevant version
checks as part of this work. While we're here, we also make the
formatting a little easier on the eye in places.

Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
volume: Add missing 'volume backup *' options

Add a couple of missing options to each command:

  volume backup create
    --no-incremental
    --property
    --availability-zone

  volume backup set
    --property

Most of these are version dependent so we add the relevant version
checks as part of this work. While we're here, we also make the
formatting a little easier on the eye in places.

Change-Id: I328d5c981cb32b2ee9a4b1bd43aa36b22347ff63
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

subject: volume: Add 'volume message *' commands
messages:
[{'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-03-19 11:58:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 27900, 'date': '2021-03-19 15:09:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I would really like to see us adding new commands using SDK from the beginning to avoid double work.
This patch may be actually used to work together with our NDSU students to do that.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-03-19 15:29:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1
> 
> (1 comment)
> 
> I would really like to see us adding new commands using SDK from the beginning to avoid double work.
> This patch may be actually used to work together with our NDSU students to do that.

While I am in favour of avoiding double work, doing this in two steps - one to add the command using the existing project specific client and another to migrate to openstacksdk - means we only have to worry about one potentially broken thing at a time and makes it a lot easier. For better or worse, the project-specific clients are battle tested. For compute, closing all the gaps with novaclient CLI using the novaclient bindings was easy (though tedious, of course). Now that I've done that, I can keep the vast majority of the code and simply change the client being called as we continue to fill in openstacksdk gaps. It's much easier this way IMO"}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-03-19 15:46:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-03-19 15:47:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-03-19 15:48:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(4 comments)

Fixed the pep8 issues'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-05-26 10:51:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-06-03 17:01:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 27900, 'date': '2021-06-18 11:38:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
volume: Add 'volume message *' commands

This patch implements the necessary commands to utilize the Messages API
introduced in Cinder API version 3.3. Version 3.5 built upon this by
implementing pagination support for these commands which is present in
this patch as well.

  volume message get
  volume message list
  volume message delete

Change-Id: I64aa0b4a8d4468baa8c63e5e30ee31de68df999d

commit_message:
volume: Add 'volume attachment *' commands

These mirror the 'cinder attachment-*' commands, with arguments copied
across essentially verbatim. The only significant departure is the
replacement of "tenant" terminology with "project".

  volume attachment create
  volume attachment delete
  volume attachment list
  volume attachment complete
  volume attachment set
  volume attachment show

Full support for filtering is deferred for now since that's a more
complicated change that requires additional commands be added first.
TODOs are included to this effect.

Change-Id: If47c2b56fe65ee2cee07c000d6ae3688d5ef3b42
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2021-06-15 14:13:47.000000000', 'message': 'build-test-package: Set distro for downstream case

`use_upstream_spec` is set to true in downstream case in [1],
If we use upstream spec we should correctly set distro otherwise
rpm-master will be used and rpm build can fail for older branches
because spec is from master.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart-extras/src/branch/master/roles/build-test-packages/templates/projects.ini.j2#L34

Change-Id: I27e1589c2ff9f2ca16bb162e0661375c96e095be
'}]
commit_message:
build-test-package: Set distro for downstream case

`use_upstream_spec` is set to true in downstream case in [1],
If we use upstream spec we should correctly set distro otherwise
rpm-master will be used and rpm build can fail for older branches
because spec is from master.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart-extras/src/branch/master/roles/build-test-packages/templates/projects.ini.j2#L34

Change-Id: I27e1589c2ff9f2ca16bb162e0661375c96e095be

commit_message:
Allows LDAP extra attributes to be exposed to the end user

When configuring the ldap driver, there is the possibility to add
extra attributes to the user/group. This allows those attributes
to be exposed to the API results.

Change-Id: If7eeb8b09ef8fd5d7879eb13b6430a7e8a30f826
Closes-Bug: #1839441

commit_message:
Literal substituted with DEFAULT_VALIDATIONS_BASEDIR

The existing constant evaluates to the prefix of another constant.
No need to keep them separate.

Arguably, the risk of someone changing one of the constants,
without the other, is already minimal. But it's better to be
extra sure.

Signed-off-by: Jiri Podivin <jpodivin@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ic5d7bf8e440a44105bf00866ca92a085a0826500

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-11 14:25:03.000000000', 'message': 'Removing the 'PIP_+' string from tox.ini

Presence of the string causes following error,
when running molecule tests on local:
'Error: error parsing host environment variables: name "PIP_+  VIRTUAL_ENV" has white spaces, poorly formatted name'

After removing it the molecule tests are able to run successfuly.

Furthermore I found no reference to the purpose of the string
in either the tox documentation, or by searching for the same
string on github. It appears we are the only project hosting code
on the service, using this particular setting.

I therefore assume that it is nonessential.

Signed-off-by: Jiri Podivin <jpodivin@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I61641a1d4ddd017451b4aa7aea1e6eae6439b53d
'}]
commit_message:
Removing the 'PIP_+' string from tox.ini

Presence of the string causes following error,
when running molecule tests on local:
'Error: error parsing host environment variables: name "PIP_+  VIRTUAL_ENV" has white spaces, poorly formatted name'

After removing it the molecule tests are able to run successfuly.

Furthermore I found no reference to the purpose of the string
in either the tox documentation, or by searching for the same
string on github. It appears we are the only project hosting code
on the service, using this particular setting.

I therefore assume that it is nonessential.

Signed-off-by: Jiri Podivin <jpodivin@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I61641a1d4ddd017451b4aa7aea1e6eae6439b53d

- gate-openstack-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/09/257809/2/check/gate-openstack-specs-docs/c517dfc//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 18s'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2016-02-09 15:51:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

This spec makes reasonable sense. What seems to be missing is why or how this is properly a cross-project spec. Is it cross project because it involves multiple projects (which is reasonable enough) or because it envision a feature which is sort of "above" some services? Is that what it means to be cross-project (in this context) or is cross-project something that involves most projects?

If there's reasonable consensus on the implementation it may make as much sense to take three specs to nova, ceilo, mistral to make things go.

I don't know what the right thing is, just trying to understand the mechanisms.'}, {'account_id': 13692, 'date': '2016-02-09 19:50:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Chris,

IMHO, this bp is cross-project in a way that it involved multiple projects.

Moreover, Timofey intentions was (IIUC) to propose an idea, that based on the information how bad host state is, the appropriate action will be selected - in worst case scenario it would be evacuation (resurrection). On other case - like we have failed compute service but working libvirt - it might be live migration, or an email to the admin or any other operation required for manual intervention.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2016-03-01 09:01:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Yes, this involves Mistral, Nova, infra services (pacemaker/corosync), so it looks like a cp one'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2016-03-01 12:16:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Also in the future this would ideally involve Congress to allow cloud operators to determine which VMs/hypervisors would receive auto-evacuation.  This could be based on several different policies, e.g. depending on the project, availability zone, etc.

I'll try to provide a full review for this change soon."}, {'account_id': 8878, 'date': '2016-03-14 03:13:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)

I'm in the neutral for the spec, but have some comments."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2016-03-15 10:19:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

The concepts are fine. I don't think a spec like this is a cross project spec. It looks largely like a mistral spec, with no real discussion or questions from the other projects.

Please don't use specs this way. A cross project spec should either be a thing which affects nearly all openstack projects, or a thing that all the projects involved have agreed to already, but need the TC for some other reason engaged on this. I'm not sure I see either in this document."}, {'account_id': 15397, 'date': '2016-03-15 16:15:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8716, 'date': '2016-03-15 21:34:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 13692, 'date': '2016-03-16 06:20:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2016-03-16 09:15:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6537, 'date': '2016-03-16 12:38:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

i believe this functionality exists across.

- Nova can send notifications when an error occurs
- Ceilometer can receive these notifications and can also poll health/status of resources
- Aodh can support rules to alert if an error notification is received (and can be improved to alert if a resource is down)
- Heat can trigger appropriate 'auto-evacuation' when Aodh alert is received.

i think that either the functionality for this exists OR can be improved in the various projects. let me know if i misunderstand anything"}, {'account_id': 13692, 'date': '2016-03-16 13:52:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Gordon,

The only thing, which is missing in your picture is, that Nova is not the source of truth if we are talking about of compute host state. It was brought up several times with the conclusion, that Nova is not responsible for monitoring the host state.

The information what Nova vs what cluster management systems can give (obvious example is  pacemaker) is that Nova only knows about compute service which can be up and running or _possibly_ not. The "possibly" in previous sentence is crucial, since there can be several different states that compute host might be, including:

- actually not running,
- running, but the compute service is down  while libvirt, and vms are fine,
- running, but temporarily disconnected from the control plane, but not from the storage network

And here is the interesting part, which is important for having data integrity, if we rebuild vms for two last cases, you might experience data corruption, if using some kind of shared storage.

So for being sure, that nothing we can do about dead (or "dead") hosts, we have to fence them. And this is missing from your scenario.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2016-03-16 13:54:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Agree this sounds like a narrow spec about a feature in Mistral, not sure that requires (costly and lengthy) cross-project approval'}, {'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2016-03-16 19:16:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

This spec was discussed in yesterday's cross-project meeting:

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/crossproject/2016/crossproject.2016-03-15-21.01.log.html#l-34

As you can see from the first few minutes of the logs, automatic evacuation is a fairly broad initiative which could potentially involve at least 7 or 8 projects.  So I don't entirely agree with the assessment of Sean and Thierry that it's confined purely to Mistral, even though I can understand why it might look that way.

However I think I *do* agree with them, and with the general feeling within yesterday's meeting, that this document in its current form is a bit too high-level and vague in terms of specific work items to be useful a cross-project spec:

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/crossproject/2016/crossproject.2016-03-15-21.01.log.html#l-111

As suggested there by mriedem, if there are gaps in the functionality of individual projects which are blocking the way forward, we can simply propose specs for those gaps.  And architectural discussions across projects can happen over the normal channels: openstack-dev mailing list, IRC, blog posts etc.  I believe this is why Mike (Perez) suggested we abandon it:

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/crossproject/2016/crossproject.2016-03-15-21.01.log.html#l-125

Having said all that, I'm not yet too familiar with the specs process or the cross-project working group, so I reserve the right to be wrong on any of these points ;-)"}, {'account_id': 13692, 'date': '2016-03-17 06:15:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Just noticed, that spec doesn't say anything about fencing, and IMHO it is crucial for the evacuation use case."}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2016-03-21 11:06:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2016-03-21 11:08:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

Thank you all for comments! I believe we'd never have had them if the spec submitted as not a CP one, but as a project specific. So, I suggest to keep doing this one as a consensus/declarative. While finishing low-level / implementation things in the projects' scope specs."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-03-21 11:15:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified-1

(I'd fix myself, but in gerrty at the moment)"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2016-01-14 18:59:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(10 comments)

A bunch of spelling and grammar things to address, but overall I like the approach here.

However, I would, for clarity, suggest renaming this "common-role-schema" instead of "common-default-policy" because what is being described here is simply a set of role identifiers that all OpenStack cloud deployments should create by default.

Best,

-jay'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2016-01-29 18:01:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-01-29 18:07:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified+1

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 136, 'date': '2016-01-30 18:36:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

We have the following profiles:

- operator profile - console/reboot
- accounting - quota/metering/...'}, {'account_id': 5707, 'date': '2016-01-30 18:53:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2016-02-02 00:31:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8215, 'date': '2016-02-02 01:30:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2016-02-02 02:46:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

(3 comments)

Thanks for fixing the previous comments. 

I'm not sure about adding the additional really fine grained roles. This is a fairly open spec, let's discuss - i wasn't thinking that the new defaults should still be fairly simple, just better than the admin/non-admin we have now."}, {'account_id': 10670, 'date': '2016-02-02 16:50:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

this seems reasonable.

as for the really fine grained roles, i'm not sure that they will ultimately be needed but i think it's a good option to make them available from the beginning as i could see them providing nice options for specific cases."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2016-02-02 18:25:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 18338, 'date': '2016-02-02 18:39:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2016-02-03 10:21:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

(3 comments)

As it is I'm happy to see this go in. I've added comments to some items/comments for additional thought."}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2016-02-03 10:21:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2016-02-04 00:49:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2016-02-04 11:34:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2417, 'date': '2016-02-04 17:44:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I read this and I don't hate it. Looks like it's addressing a real problem."}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2016-02-04 23:56:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 1916, 'date': '2016-02-05 00:48:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 5707, 'date': '2016-02-05 08:09:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2016-02-08 22:49:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2016-02-09 09:05:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

This is becoming a bit too fine-grained to my taste for a common policy, but I'm fine with it if everyone is comfortable with it..."}, {'account_id': 16708, 'date': '2016-02-09 14:52:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

This sounds like a good addition to me. I think it might be a little confusing based on the number of roles and the variance there, but I think more complexity is needed.'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2016-02-09 15:10:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

I like the spec for the most part and the idea of a common policy file.  I don't think the level of granularity is a good thing though.

IMHO the sub-types under service and observer do little more than introduce complexity and a lot of confusion for the deployer.  In addition I also suspect this will lead to all sorts of crazy configurations, many of which will end up being misunderstood, or incorrect.

Any thoughts on starting with some of the parent/base levels you have and then determining if it's worthwhile to expand on them?  I'm also thinking about this in terms of implementation.  You've got a *whole lot* going on here and you're creating a pretty steep curve for implementation where I don't necessarily think it adds any value."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2016-02-09 15:11:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(2 comments)

I'm ambivalent. On my first review I was pretty positive but now that it has become more detailed I find myself having some concerns:

* this is getting heavy and long, unless I'm misunderstanding something the volume of all the policy.json files will be quite large. This is a problem for human consumption

* related: As we're talking about universal default policies here, it really bothers me that we (OpenStack) traditionally package configuration in its full and huge form. I'd much rather the defaults live in code and documentation and the lack of file mean "use the defaults" (it means this in _some_ cases) and the presence of a file mean "these are overrides of the defaults, which live elsewhere". This how things mostly work but isn't how things are mostly packaged or coded.

The proposal seems to be suggesting that there shoiuld be default policy _files_. I'm wondering if there shouldn't be default _policies_.'}, {'account_id': 7198, 'date': '2016-02-09 15:43:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

This looks like it is headed in the right direction.  A few items that should be addressed though.'}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2016-02-09 16:09:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(9 comments)'}, {'account_id': 17860, 'date': '2016-02-09 18:23:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2016-02-09 21:04:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(11 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2016-02-09 21:14:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

I am +1 on most of this spec - I think it has gone far too detailed in the naming though.

{service_type}_{api_capability} is too far - especially in the default config.

ditto for {service_type}_{api_resource]_manager

I like the break out of service, project and admin basic roles, but breaking down API resources / capabilities is too much for the default role list.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2016-02-09 21:57:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2016-02-09 21:58:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

@Graham,

So this is also a policy file that means the roles can be created and used but are not required to as a default.'}, {'account_id': 7191, 'date': '2016-02-09 22:02:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1207, 'date': '2016-02-10 18:25:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

I find myself agreeing with John Griffith here - there's a great deal of change in this spec without much real-world to hang it on. Particularly for a cross project spec such as this, I think we'd be better off trying to do a well understood subset (the {service}_admin roles for example) and trying to get those merged in most/all services, then take it forward with more roles if there is a clear need for them.

The fine details of policy are going to be very, very deployment specific, and I don't think there is much value is guessing what people need, better to let the early adoptors come back with specific feedback."}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2016-02-10 18:32:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

@Morgan I know that - but I do think that this is too far. 

{service_type}_{api_capability} is a permission not a role.

Roles should be made up of permissions - and granting multiple users multiple roles that are the same, is not ideal. 
They should be combined into a custom role for that deployment.'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2016-02-15 22:45:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2016-02-17 02:06:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(12 comments)'}, {'account_id': 13781, 'date': '2016-02-19 14:25:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 13781, 'date': '2016-02-19 15:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: -Code-Review

I also wanted to mention the OpenStack UX, Product WG and foundation are working on a set of personas for the community.  We were hoping to align with this effort.
Note that the group of personas will also includes individuals that may not log into horizon and an admin, project owner or service admin but are involved in the decision process for the cloud.'}, {'account_id': 13781, 'date': '2016-02-19 15:33:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Link to the personas if you are interested in providing feedback.

commit_message:
A common policy scenario across all projects

All projects should provide a policy file based around a more rich
scenario than simply is a user the global admin or not.

Change-Id: I6a0957f9c1437627c6310d36d652b2fb3cb63eb9

commit_message:
Add bandit integration spec

WIP - DO NOT MERGE

With the latest release of bandit, v1.0.1, more stable functionality,
and consistant results are available. This spec will attempt to
incorporate bandit into as many OpenStack projects as possible in
order to provide a proactive security vulnerability analysis as new
code is submitted and reviewed.

Change-Id: I440c4d6a19835fcf3b87ea9cc376a96de6582fa7

commit_message:
Update min tox version to 2.0

The commands used by constraints need at least tox 2.0.  Update to
reflect reality, which should help with local running of constraints
targets.

Change-Id: I8601c28f67ca63cfef830b98727f4342aa690a42
Closes-Bug:  #1801478

[{'account_id': 9237, 'date': '2015-09-10 17:13:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 9237, 'date': '2015-09-10 17:16:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-openstack-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/93/222293/1/check/gate-openstack-specs-docs/bfced25//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 03s'}, {'account_id': 12385, 'date': '2015-09-14 01:47:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6601, 'date': '2015-09-14 21:34:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(5 comments)

Some typos'}, {'account_id': 9237, 'date': '2015-09-15 21:13:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@James Carey: Thanks for the review. I'll fix the errors in the next version."}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2015-09-18 11:17:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

I still feel strongly that the first version of this should have no dependency on Nova, it should be purely something between the instance and API user.

We can then look at if we need anything adding to Nova to make that easier to use.

I am pushing back hard because Nova has got far too big, and we are trying hard to remove things. Adding this feels like scope creep.

I would rather have a working prototype built that works outside of Nova, then look at how we integrate that system.'}, {'account_id': 9237, 'date': '2015-09-18 15:39:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@John Garbutt:

Thanks for the review.

I agree in principal that it would be nice to have it as separable/shareable as possible. So that Magnum containers or other projects could do similar things. Phase 2 authentication, as described in the proposed implementation can potentially be separated from Nova. I don't believe Phase 1 can be though, do to some of the constraints listed in the problem description. For example:
* Instances can exist for a very long time. (Pets. Years...)
* Instances can be shut down, suspended or shelved for significant periods of
time. (Can't refresh certificates before they expire)
* Instances can be snapshotted. Secrets stored on the root drive will get copied to new instances.

For your proposed solution of sending a temp url through for example, would run into issues with those constraints.

To meet those requirements:
 * Its likely the vm should store its phase 2 cert in memory. Perhaps /dev/shm/.... to prevent it from being snapshotted.
 * That means though, after reboot or shelving it would loose its phase 2 cert.
 * On pausing for significant amount of time, the phase 2 cert will expire and would need refreshing too. No software running in the vm can refresh it in time because its paused, so also needs a phase 1 refresh.

Due to the one time nature of passing a tmpurl through nova, I don't think it can be used for phase 1 authentication, nor would it be suitable for skipping phase 1 and just being a phase 2 credential. Cause once it expires, it can never be used again.

I can't think of a way to meet those constraints without having Nova "vouch" somehow for the Instance, and that's what phase 1 is about. Requiring Nova to be in the picture.

Please propose a solution you think can meet all the constrains listed in the problem description and is separable from Nova. I just can't think of a way to actually accomplish that and is secure at the same time. Thus, the proposed solution.

The security problem is weaved all through the whole workflow. If you change one piece, such as removing nova from the picture, without somehow proposing feasible adjustments to all the other pieces of the workflow to cover the parts the removed piece were accomplishing, it just breaks things. I know every project involved would like to be less involved because it simplifies their side of things and simpler is always better. But taken together as a whole, one project simplifying too much makes all the other parts more complicated and the whole solution may be overly complicated and less secure.

What's a solution that meets the problem description and has Nova minimally involved? The proposed solution is the close as I've been able to come to that.

Or alternately, maybe we just don't agree on the problem description yet? Are the constraints unreasonable?

Thanks,
Kevin'}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2015-09-22 01:39:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7063, 'date': '2015-10-09 12:53:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(9 comments)

A few concerns and nits.'}, {'account_id': 7063, 'date': '2015-10-27 02:46:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

We'll be discussing this and an alternative approach at the Tokyo summit : http://sched.co/4Qdq"}, {'account_id': 9237, 'date': '2015-10-27 05:11:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

Yes. Ill be there. Also, there is a Nova cross services issues session a little later that day. we will be discussing it there and your welcome to come too.'}, {'account_id': 7063, 'date': '2015-11-01 03:54:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thinking on the conversations we've had this week. Is the main concern in using the metadata service that "sometimes it wont be there" or that "it can't be trusted" ?

If the latter is the case, perhaps we could look at ways to make the metadata more trustworthy and pass information to instances that way?'}, {'account_id': 9237, 'date': '2015-11-01 14:47:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Both. Sometimes its not there. Sometimes its there but cant be trusted. For example with nova md+kvm, antispoofing rules in kvm ensure the request comes only from the correct vm. But with ironic instances, there is no way to do that. They have direct access to the hardware so spoofing can happen.'}, {'account_id': 9237, 'date': '2015-11-25 22:53:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm going to take a break from this and work on something less frustrating for a while.

I felt pretty disrespected at the summit where we were to talk about this, and I had to interrupt multiple times 10 minutes from the end of the session to talk about it and only one other person actually read the spec. We then spent the 10 minutes talking about trivial things that are already covered in the spec.

And the outcome of it all was a recommendation to create more specs! I've spent months writing specs that I feel hardly anyone reads. What assurance do I have that I won't be further wasting time writing more specs people critical to the process wont read?

Please, PTL's, give me some assurance that the projects will take this problem seriously, and I might take it back up quickly again. Otherwise, it might be a while... This will hurt many other projects such as the app catalog but I don't think it can be helped. :/

I waited a while after the summit to see if this was something I just needed to cool off over, but its almost 4 weeks later and I still feel the same way. So, I need to go write some code now, rather then just talk about the possibility of writing code endlessly. I can't work like this. :/

Thanks,
Kevin"}, {'account_id': 1528, 'date': '2015-11-27 03:08:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(10 comments)

I'm interested in this to solve my sshd server certificates use case. It was a while since Tokyo, and I didn't get involved straight away, but I'm keen to work with you Kevin to get this finished.

There are a few more comments I'd like to leave later, but I'm trying to go through this, old comments, and the vm-integration spec first.

There are some things I think may help with the spec and I could help out with - specifically the big part I'm missing is "what are we protecting from and how does it justify each element". Most of it is there, but spread out over the text so I'll try to extract a specific list and see if it improves things.

If you'd like me to help with anything specific or to chat about the ideas, please reach out on email. I don't want this spec to die :)'}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2016-03-11 19:15:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hey Kevin, this spec has been getting stale. Do we want to revive things and bring it up in the next cross-project meeting?https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Meetings/CrossProjectMeeting'}, {'account_id': 9237, 'date': '2016-03-11 19:59:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Probably a good idea. The use cases hasn't gone away. We've just been turning users away with no good path forward. For our new cloud region, we haven't installed Barbican so far since there's not a good way to use it yet. :/

I am reluctant to do any more spec writing though without some more commitment from the various teams. I've sent a huge amount of time spec writing with very little path forward right now.

I'm attending the Austin summit, so maybe we can all get together and talk about it again there and reach some kind of consensus on a path forward?

Thanks,
Kevin"}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2016-04-06 20:59:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

See my comment on line 137 to an alternative workflow which is, I think, as secure as we can get this.'}, {'account_id': 9237, 'date': '2016-04-06 21:46:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I like the idea of generating the keypair on the host and storing the pubkey in the nova database associated with the vm.

nova supports instances that are physical machines (ironic) so reading the physical disk can not be the only option.

Reusing the vm's primary disk would also be a security risk to have to parse through the file system. attaching a second block device that the vm writes the raw key to would be an option for a plugin for phase 1 auth though. An extra serial port would be too.

But we have to support some other mechanism for ironic nodes.

Thanks,
Kevin"}, {'account_id': 9237, 'date': '2016-04-11 23:48:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(21 comments)'}, {'account_id': 9237, 'date': '2016-04-11 23:54:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

We have a summit session dedicated to this spec. Please attend so we can discuss this further:
https://www.openstack.org/summit/austin-2016/summit-schedule/events/9485'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2016-04-21 13:36:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

For reference, in the last summit session on this, we agreed this would be updated to describe how this could work security with no "help" from Nova.

With that in place, we could look at how Nova can make the process more automated/integrated if needed.

See:
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/mitaka-nova-service-users'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2016-04-21 13:40:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2016-04-21 13:41:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think the best way to inject a key is using the existing config drive / metadata service system.

But I would like a clear description of how this works without Nova doing anything, so its clear how Nova can help make it easier.'}, {'account_id': 9237, 'date': '2016-04-21 15:42:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@John Garbutt: To say we "agreed" at the last summit to writing 2 more specs is inaccurate... I'd agree to that if I thought nova would give it proper consideration but I haven't gotten any feed back that nova is willing to do anything but stonewall putting any new code in nova. Do you believe it will receive proper consideration if I spend a bunch more time writing more specs? So far, it feels very fruitless.

That being said, Config drive is a one shot deal. I keep asking and not getting any answer about it, how does getting fresh Keys after they have expired due to the several reasons listed in the spec work without Nova's help? I've got many vm's now that are over a year old in some clouds. Some suspended for months. I don't think your suggestion can be made to work, at all, and meet all the requirements. I don't think that idea is viable at all. Please help me understand how I'm wrong here. I don't understand. I can't write the requested spec if I can't understand how it would work at all. If the idea of not involving Nova at all can be made to work, with all the requirements of the spec being met, I'd be for it, because that would be a path forward. Right now, I don't see a path forward without Nova, and Nova doesn't seem to want to be involved. :/'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2016-06-21 10:16:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Kevin, so I only just noticed your comment here, sorry.

Clearly we all went away with different ideas from that summit session last year, apologies for that.

Nova was attempting to say, please come back with a prototype (be that real or theoretical) that makes clear exactly what is required from Nova and why. We were not trying to ask for the writing multiple specs.

Agreed my suggestion has lots of issues. The point was really just to have a clear discussion of what works without Nova, so its clear what is really needed in Nova, and why. We were all struggling to understand the problem and why it needs the proposed solution.

If we have a clear (partial) solution that doesn't involve Nova, its going to be much clearer to see what is missing, and why.

The use case at the top of my head is Magnum distributing the secret key for the API between multiple VMs. In that case, it seems acceptable for the secret to live on the system disk. Agreed that could "leak" via snapshot and lots of other ways, but as I understood it, that token only has limited access that is scoped to the particular instance. I was assuming there would be some amount of key rotation, to limit that risk.

Now I agree that is not going to be acceptable for all users and use cases. One alternative, as you say is to keep they key in memory, and create a new VM if you loose it (via reboot, or whatever).

Now with those two cases, there are likely some use cases that are not well served. If we have the basic scenario implemented, its going to be much easier to look at supporting the extra use cases, and understanding the cost of that work. We don't currently have any channel we consider secure between the VM and Nova. That will need some investigation to have something that works across all our hypervisor drivers (or network drivers).'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2016-06-21 14:31:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

From Magnum's point of view, it is unacceptable to store secrets in VM's disk, although we do that for now because there is no better alternative. The secrets Magnum wants to distribute is an OpenStack account used by the VMs to talk to other OpenStack services. For example, Magnum has a private registry feature that needs to push/pull docker images to/from Swift. There is external load balancer feature that needs to talk to the neutron lbaas. There is a data volume feature that needs to talk to Cinder to provision volumes at runtime. So far, there is no prefect way to "scope" a credential. The solution we are using is Keystone trust, but it has several issues. Also, there is no key rotation in Magnum.

From my point of view, the ideal solution is to have a way to scope the credentials to VMs, so that the credentials cannot be used outside of the VMs.'}, {'account_id': 9237, 'date': '2016-06-22 23:46:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@John

> @Kevin, so I only just noticed your comment here, sorry.

> Clearly we all went away with different ideas from that summit session last year, apologies for that.

Thanks. I'm not trying to be adversarial or stubborn or anything here. I'm just really burnt out/frustrated on this. I do appreciate your time. If I sound grumpy, Its not because of you. Just frustrated...

> Nova was attempting to say, please come back with a prototype (be that real or theoretical) that makes clear exactly what is required from Nova and why. We were not trying to ask for the writing multiple specs.

I'm ok doing prototypes instead of specs, but have run into the same issues before. Without some agreement that it should be done, then the prototype isn't given much consideration. I've implemented solutions now several times, and written several specs and gotten nowhere. I don't think the prototypes have been looked at really closely, nor the specs. Its incredibly frustrating how much time I've burned on this activity and gotten nothing to show for it. I'm having a very hard time justifying burning more time on it when there are other things to work on that are also biting me, and are actually solvable, so I need to have a path forward that has some reasonable hope of success for me to continue.

I organized a fairly large summit session in Austin and neither the Nova PTL nor any Nova core considered it important enough to show. That makes me not want to work on it further without some stronger backing. The idea of just sliding something into nova-api's pastebin we came up with then didn't pan out after studying it fully against the requirements and it kind of felt to me like a horrible hack anyway to work around the lack of Nova's support. So, another non viable partial solution again.

I think the only way forward I can see, is to get a few Nova Cores to spawn a small work group, and I can really spend some time describing the problem to them and get everyone on the same page... Its seems like its a difficult problem to get a grasp on, and the time folks can spend on reviewing a spec or reviewing a prototype, or attending a 50 minute summit session doesn't allow enough time/feedback to really understand the problem.

Based on turnout though, It really does seem to be a very common problem.

> Agreed my suggestion has lots of issues. The point was really just to have a clear discussion of what works without Nova, so its clear what is really needed in Nova, and why. We were all struggling to understand the problem and why it needs the proposed solution.

> If we have a clear (partial) solution that doesn't involve Nova, its going to be much clearer to see what is missing, and why.

The problem with implementing the partial solution, is I feel its a waste of time. The partial solution is not extendable to the real solution. I feel all it will do is to prove to some folks that haven't taken the time to fully understand the problem, as a "good enough" solution to be accepted instead of the harder, real one. I'm not really interested in enabling that. :/ OpenStack already has a lot of partial solutions that don't sum up to useful solutions. I know, in some ways, thats why Nova's pushing back now. It has a lot of them its supporting now. Lets solve it for real.

> The use case at the top of my head is Magnum distributing the secret key for the API between multiple VMs. In that case, it seems acceptable for the secret to live on the system disk. Agreed that could "leak" via snapshot and lots of other ways, but as I understood it, that token only has limited access that is scoped to the particular instance. I was assuming there would be some amount of key rotation, to limit that risk.

No, Magnum doesn't work that way. The whole point of this spec originally was to create a method to allow credentials to be scoped to a vm. Thats why the original spec didn't have keystone credentials being handed to vm's at all, but vms could request temporary keystone tokens from Nova, that would be very short lived. Thats exactly how AWS does it. The spec has since become much more complicated to handle the reality that Nova has backends where the metatdata server can't be trusted. At its heart, it still does that though. Provide a temporary credential for the instance that can be revoked/refreshed as needed.

> Now I agree that is not going to be acceptable for all users and use cases. One alternative, as you say is to keep they key in memory, and create a new VM if you loose it (via reboot, or whatever).

I'm mostly interested in solving the issues I actually experience daily, not the academic.

Creating a new vm when a reboot happens is not a viable solution. I have nova launched vm's that are pets that literally are multiple years old. For example:
| OS-SRV-USG:launched_at               | 2014-05-30T20:57:15.000000                               |

It was launched back when the cloud was Icehouse on SL6 and I've carried it forward through 3 major OpenStack upgrades and a OS upgrade from SL6->SL7. In a few months, we're going to Mitaka.

As we release our new cloud to more non computer scientists, that kind of thing is unfortunately going to become much much more common for us. :/

> Now with those two cases, there are likely some use cases that are not well served. If we have the basic scenario implemented, its going to be much easier to look at supporting the extra use cases, and understanding the cost of that work. We don't currently have any channel we consider secure between the VM and Nova. That will need some investigation to have something that works across all our hypervisor drivers (or network drivers).

I think the possible implementations for the real solution vs the partial are so different it won't help much.

Your right, there isnt a single secure channel. Thats why the proposal switched to making it plug-able. I'm afraid that's the only way to deal with the fact Nova's virtualization is plugable too. The most secure solution for kvm is totally different then ironic backed with standard BMC's or different yet from ironic backed with Dell DRACS, or what LXC can do.

Really, the spec has been made as simple as I can figure out how to do while meeting the requirements. As gathered from personal experience running several production clouds, and the feedback from the Keystone, Barbican and Nova teams.

I could go and prototype the whole spec, but its unfortunately going to be a lot of work, for someone with no experience with the nova code base, on something I'm not sure the Nova team will ever accept. Its a problem.

Does the WG sound like a viable solution to you?

Thanks,
Kevin'}, {'account_id': 9237, 'date': '2016-06-22 23:51:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Hongbin Lu
The originally implementation was literally a metadata api call to get a Keystone Token for the vm, and was very short lived. The vm could call at any time to get a fresh one so that the vm had to continue to re-prove it was itself. If a token ever escaped, it would be quickly invalidated. Thats how it works on AWS.

The current spec lengthens that time a bit, as some of the secure channels might be much slower then the metadata server, but the Cert lifetime can be made relatively short too, so can be run in a similar way. I don't think there is really a way to truely restrict a credential to a vm, other then make it short lived and have the vm have to re-prove its identity frequently to get a fresh one. Then any stolen tokens expire.

Thats what this spec is about."}, {'account_id': 9664, 'date': '2016-07-29 16:07:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 17860, 'date': '2016-09-02 14:02:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2017-05-02 15:19:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

How does the vendordata v2 metadata API code that was added in Newton:

https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/newton/implemented/vendordata-reboot.html

https://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/vendordata.html

And enhanced in Ocata:

https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/ocata/implemented/vendordata-reboot-ocata.html

Help with this? With that the guest should be able to make a request to the metadata service API to proxy a request to an external pluggable REST API (vendordatav2) which provides whatever it wants to the guest.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2017-07-18 00:18:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> How does the vendordata v2 metadata API code that was added in Newton ... Help with this?

Does that work for all types of deployments (metadata server only, configdrive-only, Ironic), or only ones that use the metadata server?'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2017-07-29 21:57:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This is roughly what the recent metadata server changes were to auto-enroll a VM with an identity provider.  It seems that a modification of the server code to make that registration happen with Keystone as opposed to a separate IdP would be the easiest way to implement this.  

Since the instance user is going to make calls from the VM, the image used has to be modified to take advantage of this.  Thus, it should not involve Nova at all.

Requesting feedback from the Auto-registration Metadata server folks.'}, {'account_id': 9237, 'date': '2017-07-29 23:27:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> This is roughly what the recent metadata server changes were to
 > auto-enroll a VM with an identity provider.  It seems that a
 > modification of the server code to make that registration happen
 > with Keystone as opposed to a separate IdP would be the easiest way
 > to implement this.
 > 
 > Since the instance user is going to make calls from the VM, the
 > image used has to be modified to take advantage of this.  Thus, it
 > should not involve Nova at all.
 > 
 > Requesting feedback from the Auto-registration Metadata server
 > folks.

External metadata extension would work for a subset of what the spec is talking about. It would not work for sites that do not run the metadata server at all, nor for ironic? I think those cases would still require nova support.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2017-07-30 20:48:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Nova is supported, as they wrote the extension to work with TripleO, which uses Ironic.  It might require something config-drive specific for some deployments, but I think that is a reasonable extension.

Without Meta-data, Nova cannot do you much good.  We worked through a lot of these scenarios before coming up with the meta-data approach. Nova is unlikely to budge on that front, based on the discussions we had.

Suggest you shelve this proposal for the time being and see if you can work with the Metadata approach first.  If there is a meta-data-server-less approach required, we can revisit.'}, {'account_id': 26553, 'date': '2017-12-05 02:28:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2021-06-18 16:28:52.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This repo is retiring https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-specs/+/796963'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2015-09-10 17:13:26.000000000', 'message': 'Instance Users for Cloud Interaction

Instances have need to some times interact with the cloud that it is
running under. This can include getting keys from Barbican, putting
messages in a Zaqar queue, getting a file from Swift, etc. All of
these services require a fresh Keystone token.

APIImpact

Change-Id: I86a994ca94e2d6a2a4e3753ffab107afc38d3dec
'}]
commit_message:
Instance Users for Cloud Interaction

Instances have need to some times interact with the cloud that it is
running under. This can include getting keys from Barbican, putting
messages in a Zaqar queue, getting a file from Swift, etc. All of
these services require a fresh Keystone token.

APIImpact

Change-Id: I86a994ca94e2d6a2a4e3753ffab107afc38d3dec

Perhaps the <keyword> here should be following the service types authority repo which is still being defined:

https://review.openstack.org/#/q/project:+openstack/service-types-authority

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-February/085748.html'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2016-04-20 21:14:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I'm hoping this is meant to expand on the resource naming described in http://docs.openstack.org/developer/python-openstackclient/commands.html#objects.  (Yes, we need to change the docs to use 'resource' rather than 'object'.)

I really really want to discourage the blanket use of namespaces in commands, they are a) not necessary everywhere, and b) require the user to now know which namespace a resource exists in to find it, removing one of the reasons to unify the commands in the first place.

Resources should be named descriptively.  There are a number of existing resources that were named when there were only 5 OpenStack projects, so descriptive qualification was not required.  Those names are considered grandfathered, although we will likely introduce descriptive aliases for some of them, particularly the more recent additions such as the snapshot example given.

Using that example, 'volume snapshot' gets that name not because it is a 'cinder command' or because it is part of the volume API, but because it is a snapshot of a volume.  Those all give the same result in this case, but there is a huge distinction that is important to understand and make clear in a spec like this.

A good example for where the API name is not the qualifier for a resource is with 'flavor'.  Multiple APIs either already use or want to use 'flavor' as a resource.  The existing flavor resource will likely be aliased to 'server flavor' in the future to clearly distinguish it from other flavors such as Zaqar's 'message flavor'.

As resource named are created, they should be 'registered' in the OSC docs as shown in http://docs.openstack.org/developer/python-openstackclient/commands.html#objects."}, {'account_id': 8246, 'date': '2016-04-21 05:35:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 16308, 'date': '2016-04-21 17:07:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I agree with dtroyer on this and would suggest to base this spec on resource... 
for ex, backup and snapshot commands should prefix with volume as they are specific to volume resource..'}, {'account_id': 16308, 'date': '2016-04-21 18:22:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Published edit on patch set 1'}, {'account_id': 16308, 'date': '2016-04-21 18:23:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Just updated for Jenkins shouts...'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2016-04-21 18:42:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I agree with Dean. I'm not sure we need a spec for this so much as elaborating the existing instructions he refers to."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-04-21 20:02:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-openstack-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/60/308460/2/check/gate-openstack-specs-docs/9f3623d//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 4m 11s'}, {'account_id': 17405, 'date': '2016-04-21 21:54:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Currently I am in the middle of addressing Dean's and Mike's comments, so I will push up a new patch set soon.

@Dean, yes you are correct that the purpose of this spec is meant to expand on how resources are being named. I also agree that this spec needs to provide a clearer distinction under âThe Keyword Approachâ about naming the resource descriptively and not naming it based on a certain API or project."}, {'account_id': 18479, 'date': '2016-04-22 16:04:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-04-22 16:08:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

Provided more information in the 'Propsed Change' and 'Alternatives' sections of the spec. Jacob was having some technical difficulties, so we worked on it in my environment and pushed it up."}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2016-04-23 06:24:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

looks good, i like the effort to standardize this'}, {'account_id': 17860, 'date': '2016-09-02 12:49:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

I echo Steve's comment: I like the effort to standardize this"}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2016-09-20 09:16:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote-1

Sounds like Dean and Steve are on board with making certain commands more distinct like 'server flavor' and 'message flavor' ... I don't think we really need a cross-project effort since the OSC team just needs to enforce it."}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2016-09-20 13:45:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

@Mike - how can the OSC team enforce it across the plugins?

If we are looking at the built in OSC commands, this spec is not needed, but if we want to take into account the large amount of other projects not in that limited selection, this is definitely a cross project issue.

We could look at what we did for the designate-dashboard, where the designate-dashboard-core team is designate-core + horizon-core, but that would need a cross project spec ....'}, {'account_id': 8246, 'date': '2016-12-27 05:39:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
OSC command naming convention

In OSC when developers are implementing commands from their
specific project, there are no guidelines or convention for
them to follow. This can potentially cause issues where the
user is left confused of what a command actually does if the
developer uses a broad command name. This spec proposes
introducing a guideline for naming new commands.

Co-Authored-By: Slade Baumann <baumann@us.ibm.com>
Co-Authored-By: Jacob Gregor <jgregor@us.ibm.com>
Co-Authored-By: Sheel Rana <ranasheel2000@gmail.com>

Change-Id: Iaa112614178cc937de0da675826661a313990ceb

commit_message:
Drop MANIFEST.in - it's not needed by pbr

Openstack-specs already uses PBR:- setuptools.setup(
                    setup_requires=['pbr'],
                    pbr=True)

This patch removes `MANIFEST.in` file as pbr generates a
sensible manifest from git files and some standard files
and it removes the need for an explicit `MANIFEST.in` file.

Change-Id: I33b182538e3243b13f78b917ef47cc15de54f4c5

commit_message:
Remove pbr warnerrors in favor of sphinx check

This change removes the now unused "warnerrors" setting, which is
replaced by "warning-is-error" in sphinx releases >= 1.5 [1].

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-March/113085.html

Change-Id: I1e53ebd014a09a3a3453e86aebcd9eb5d48a5bb7
Closes-Bug:#1693670

- gate-openstack-specs-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/54/284454/1/check/gate-openstack-specs-docs/0202439//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 41s'}, {'account_id': 2537, 'date': '2016-02-24 23:43:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Great start Vilobh! 

Thanks for the spec.__init__'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2016-02-25 01:02:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Awesome :)'}, {'account_id': 8246, 'date': '2016-02-25 03:24:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(7 comments)

Looks good, just not sure what kind of a library this will look like. It sounds like the proposed software has an API, a database, an engine for currency control. So ... it smells more like a project on its own foot. Could it be a sub-project of some monitoring/billing services?'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2016-02-25 15:03:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

In the past when we discussed this, we reached the conclusion that if the quota library needed to store anything in the database, and needed to define the tables to do that, then it would be better to have it implemented as a service that could own the database schema and any migrations needed to manage it. Otherwise we have to somehow find a way to inject migrations from a library into the database setup for a service, and we didn't feel like that pattern made a lot of sense.

As near as I can tell, this was discussed most recently at the Kilo summit. The Blazar project is mentioned about 2/3 of the way down the notes in https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/kilo-oslo-common-quota-library and although I don't think we agreed that was 100% the best approach I do remember the discussion quickly coming to the consensus that it should be handled by a service rather than a library."}, {'account_id': 8912, 'date': '2016-02-25 17:18:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

Thanks Vilobh for putting together this spec :)'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2016-02-26 00:53:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

So as for the library vs not, how about we start off with this spec not yet calling it a library and call it an 'entity' that we will later figure out what it is after we work through the usages, a API (that we can make be a service or a library) and the desired users of that library because IMHO that's way more important than once again rejecting this idea because of the word 'library' or 'service' (both which cause people to seize up and panic).

I'd rather get some common agreement on what this thing will do, what its api could be, then worry about things like a library or service, because IMHO that concern is pretty negligible in the larger view of things...

My 3 cents"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2016-02-26 12:13:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Josh - Sure, that's fine. I was trying to inject some history, not stop any work on this. I *would* like to see some analysis of why we need a new project instead of picking up the work Blazar included in the alternatives section of this spec."}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2016-02-26 17:09:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1297, 'date': '2016-03-30 04:52:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

So another thought that just came to my mind.

This engine concept (which I think is a good design point) could instead of having these goal-oriented functions (assign_quota being a goal, not a piece of that goal) could also take as input a small little language, let's call it a quota-descriptor-language that describes the goal in a generic manner and the engine translates that QDL into a action plan and performs it *safely*.

Something perhaps like:

  FOR user=bob DECREMENT_QUOTA BY 10 IF <COND> AND BEFORE COMMIT RUN <FUNC>

The above QDL (somewhat like SQL, but not really) would be very restricted and would be created to match what the projects would need. Then there could/would be a sole function to this engine (besides __init__ that would be execute(qdl_text)).

To me the above seems like it offers a vast improvement over what exists in nova since that language can be clearly defined, and extermely well tested by a suite of language cases/examples. Now say u want to replace the <cond> above with a python function that is called, that'd be ok, but the execution layer in the engine would be the one handling rollback if that condition fails and the BEFORE COMMIT <func> would similarily be correctly handled (when/if it raises an error)..."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2016-04-12 02:52:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

-1

Please see my extended response to the mailing list thread:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-March/090560.html

-jay'}, {'account_id': 10263, 'date': '2016-04-12 03:13:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

1. Does "reservation table" can also be regarded as part of or set of cached tables (as is the case for quota_usages) ? If yes then do we really need it ?'}, {'account_id': 12237, 'date': '2016-04-13 00:55:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 9775, 'date': '2016-05-11 06:31:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

I was not present at the design discussions in Austin and hence a couple of my questions may sound a bit trivial which I felt were not clarified in the spec.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2016-05-11 20:59:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

As a library, this means that either:
 1) the projects are coinstalled so that the data stores are all locally accessible
 2) the delimiter library has RPC/API functionality and does network requests to check/enforce quotas

I've long thought there could be some really interesting quota use cases ("customer gets XYZ TB of object storage across all of their accounts" or "customer gets XYZ requests to object storage for every compute VM deployed" or etc).  So when I see this and think about how to integrate it with Swift's existing quotas, it looks really interesting.

But how is that going to work? Swift isn't normally co-installed with other projects in production. And there's oftentimes quite a few client-facing servers in the Swift cluster (perhaps even globally distributed). So if I have a Swift cluster with 10 or more API servers (even if they are in the same region), do each of these need to talk to all the others to coordinate? Does each request to any Swift endpoint need to talk back to a central DB server? Is delimiter keeping track of all that and doing it in a performant way?

There seem to be several assumptions baked into this document that make it sound very very difficult for me to integrate into Swift. Any ideas on what a production deployment might look like?'}, {'account_id': 2537, 'date': '2016-05-11 21:59:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Hi John,

Good question. I wonder how we missed it:

* This library is intended to be a common set of computational, transnational and inter-project(tenant) semantics that will be applicable across domains in OpenStack.

* This library will only provide an abstract interface (or will attempt to provide classes that are resource/service oriented) for common set of tasks like get_ , set_, enforce_, delete_ quotas.

* It is intended to be consumed by individual projects and implement quota APIs and maintain the quota DB tables as per the project convenience/priorities/standards.

* This library will not support inter-project communication to implement PaaS level of quotas (needed by services like Trove, Magnum, etc). Those concepts can be covered once we have (hopefully consistent) quota implementation in different OpenStack services.

Hope that helps.'}, {'account_id': 2537, 'date': '2016-05-11 22:07:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

Thanks for your consideration on my inline comment.'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2016-05-11 23:34:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

OK, I think I understand a little better now.

So step one (which is where we're at now) is to have projects abstract existing quota stuff behind this library (API, really). Then, in the future, it should be much easier to do the cross project thing since all the projects have one API to use.

So does this become a client SDK style thing? Sounds like a client could call swiftclient.delimiter.set_quota() and pass the right things and get a swift-specific quota set. Is that what you're imagining?


Unrelated, "delimiter" is already a thing in Swift [1]. If this is a common way to do quotas, why don't we call it "quota_library" or "libquota" or something like that? Make it explicit and avoid overloading existing things.



[1] http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-objectstorage-v1.html#showAccountDetails and http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-objectstorage-v1.html#showContainerDetails'}, {'account_id': 10263, 'date': '2016-05-12 07:28:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Thanks Nikhil for the clarifications.

@John : You got it right. The aim or the vision of the library is to provide consistent set of API's which given a set of input by the consuming project should be able to enforce quota on behalf of that respective project. 

While making quota calculations the library will take into consideration whether the project hierarchy is flat or nested (hierarchal projects).

libquota/quota_library names sounded very methodical and I didn't want it to have some of those names so thought of "Delimiter". I wasn't aware that it overlaps with a concept in swift. Thanks for letting us know.


@Sudipto : 

#1 . Individual projects will maintain quota information. Quota information is not going anywhere it needs to be persisted somewhere and that place is respective projects.

#2. More on generation id coming soon.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2016-05-12 17:11:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

please wait to approve this until the discussion on the ML is completed http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-May/094781.html'}, {'account_id': 17860, 'date': '2016-09-02 13:16:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

(11 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2017-06-24 06:46:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

I believe with the current direction, this spec can now be abandoned.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2021-06-18 16:28:08.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This repo is retiring https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-specs/+/796963'}]

commit_message:
Delimiter - Cross Project Quota Enforcement and Management

Quotas are common and the same time complex peice of code that every project
in OpenStack needs for proper usage and management of resources. It seems
that even though it is a common requirement there is not a common entity at
present which enforces quota where as the approach taken by OpenStack is to
have every project build its own quota framework (database tables, businees
logic, etc) needed to enforce and manage quotas. Hence, this is an attempt
to build a common library so that new and existing projects can seek benefit
from it.

Change-Id: Id94d612ab5bea317a221581039f321bd649b406e
