(5 comments)

Some comments inline, also some more thoughts:

- Some resources could end up being pretty noisy with their notifications, and this could translate into lots of REST API calls to find out what happened. In a polling situation the client would have control over how often to check for news simply by setting the polling interval. Would it make sense to have something similar here? Maybe any notifications that occur in the given interval are grouped and delivered in a single payload?

- The WebSocket and long-polling connections are long lived, so they introduce different dynamics for servers. For a co-routine based server handling a large number of long term connections is not a big problem, but this service would not be able to scale if put in front of Apache (no support for WebSocket, and no co-routine based connections). Proxy servers and load balancers may or may not be friendly to WebSocket.'}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2015-05-27 06:49:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(4 comments)

Miguel: re: "Some resources could end up being pretty noisy with their notifications"

I think the event type STATE_CHANGE is largely for the use case of when you are waiting for a server/stack to get to the state that you want. In this case you really don't have many states between (normally BUILD -> ACTIVE/ERROR) which is a lot better than time based polling. With the MESSAGE type you really don't have to get the resource again  - it's all about the message. I'd expect a lot more MESSAGE type events (that you can ignore if you are waiting for the state to change).

re: the scaling, I'll need to research some more - how to loadbalance etc..'}, {'account_id': 7385, 'date': '2015-05-27 07:54:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 12606, 'date': '2015-05-27 17:03:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Angus, I think this is relevant: https://dev.twitter.com/streaming/overview/connecting

The link describes the implementation of the Twitter streaming APIs. They use long-polling for these. This page discusses their keep-alive, reconnection and rate limiting implementation, all based on HTTP.

As far as reverse proxies and load balancers, Apache is not a good solution for this type of service. I have found nginx to work extremely well in front of one or more WebSocket or long-polling HTTP servers.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2015-06-01 21:59:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

I think this needs more clarification, because I think there are two different use cases for these notifications, and it may well be that you are only focusing on one of them - which is not necessarily a bad thing, but it would be helpful to have the discussion in the broader context because the two may or may not have the same solution.

Use case 1 is notifying *applications* about events, so that they can take some sort of action:

- Relatively low volume
- Delivery must be reliable
- Support for multiple readers highly desirable but not strictly required
- Messages should contain enough metadata to allow other services (e.g. Mistral) to use them as the sole source of info about an event
- No need to buffer messages if nobody listening (can wait for explicit subscription)

Use case 2 is notifying *people* about events, messages, &c.:

- Higher volume
- Delivery can be best-effort
- Support for multiple readers required (e.g. multiple Horizon dashboards open)
- Message data can be retrieved from elsewhere
- Buffering messages from prior to connection highly desirable (but costly)

It sounds like you're aiming more toward the second use case (which will be a really nice UX improvement, but not a transformative improvement to OpenStack like the first would be IMHO)."}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2015-06-02 04:29:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

Zane thanks for the great feedback! Hopefully we can get a great discussion going here.

I agree with much of what you are saying, I'll dump some thoughts here (but actually I was aiming at the first use-case more).

This design will handle multiple readers when we have just one instance of it. But I am struggling to see it if we start up multiple services for scaling - thanks for catching that.

Consumers

 re: 1. programs that wait for a specific event to action something
 - rich event body? - optional IMHO, but metadata more
   important than textual message, if we have auth then non-issue

 re: 2. horizon/cli event list 
 (user wants to keep a record of all events from their infra)
 - persistent, good filtering (show by request-id, resource uuid, tenant)
 - could be purely a REST API (websocket nice to have)
 - implicit registration
 - nice textual message important
 - scalable storage


Solutions

Some references:
 - https://github.com/pubsubhubbub
 - http://blog.caplin.com/2011/01/13/pubsubhubbub-vs-client- push-technologies-whats-the-difference/

The above articles are interesting and suggest that service-to-service events would be better serviced by webhooks and service-to-client needs to be websockets (or similar). 

Reasons to choose webhooks over websockets

 - your interest is really long lived (you don't want to hold a socket open for ages)
 - you don't require subsecond response
 - you have a rest api that can accept a webhook

Reasons to choose websockets over webhooks
- you don't have a REST API
- you don't want to listen for events for a long period of time
- you do want quick response

pubsubhubbub

There are 3 parts to this, the hub (basically the notification system), the blog server (basically distrubted storage for the atom feed we *could* use http://atomhopper.org/) and the aggregator. This separates out the storing of the events, the notification of events (webhook) and the aggregation of events across services.

zaqar
In zaqar the notification and storage are in one place and we don't have aggregation. 

If we used pubsubhubbub/blog feed as a model (take 1)

 1. each OpenStack service would store their own events (olso lib to make this easier) and make it accessable via REST
 2. we have a mechanism for pinging the "hub/notifier service" when there are new messages
 3. the notifier calls all subscribed webhooks with new events
 4. the aggregator updates it's clients (websocket)

This model has it's problems:
 1. openstack services have the same db so we don't get a storage benefit for the "distrubtedness" of the design (this  one advantage of my initial design of just returning a link (the state is already stored in the services' DB)
 2. we have to implement a lot of /messages API in each service - which is a pita
 
OK so take 2

 1. all services send zaqar (notifier+storage) events to resource specific queues
 2. we make an aggregator (maybe part of zaqar) that allows the user to subscribe multiple queues into one
 3. add websocket support to zaqar

problems with this:
 1. a feed != queue, queues don't normally allow listing and random reading
 
So do we need feeds/inboxs or queues?

- For actionable items, been able to "claim" a message so it doesn't get actioned twice is great
- For user "messages/events" this does not make sense, here we want more of an Inbox/feed

Take 3

So if zaqar had a /messages or /feeds that had no concept of queuing (claims) - maybe a thin layer over swift to store the messages then we could use this as a base and the user asks an aggregator to copy messages (from potentially multiple inboxes) into a queue for them to get the queue like semantics (if they need them). If the user just needs websocket events then they just get a stream from the /messages.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2015-06-05 20:52:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Take 2 sounds a lot closer to what we want. The big downside is that we'll be sending messages for everything, all the time, even if nothing is listening. But the advantage is that you can handle all the subscriptions through this one service, rather than every service having to add stuff to its API to manage subscriptions.

The inverse properties would be offered by something like what AWS does (see http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/cfn-console-add-tags.html under Notification Options) where you provide an SNS topic for notifications to be sent to. At the Summit we talked about doing something equivalent in Heat.

I think the term 'queuing' is actually a red herring here... maybe we should just say 'topic'. Zaqar is not about queuing per se, just about messaging. Then we can talk about how many consumers there are and what sort of semantics they need and whether Zaqar's semantics can support that efficiently."}, {'account_id': 6537, 'date': '2015-06-09 07:16:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

so i'm not really sure how we're differientiating the current notifications openstack emits and these 'user' notification -- i think the categorisation is highly subjective. also, tbh the state/property_change types seem to be identical to many of the current notifications that are emitted

this seems like rather than duplicating functionality, this could all be consumed by ceilometer[1]/existing notification consumers and the visible results be configured through policies.

[1] for transparency, i may/may not have a bias. see my current position."}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2015-06-10 02:16:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Gordon

"so i'm not really sure how we're differientiating the current notifications openstack emits and these 'user' notification -- i think the categorisation is highly subjective."

I think the main issue is the audience (RPC notifications are for operators and the "events" I am trying to describe here are for end-users). At summit many in the session were nervous that end user events could end up having operator sensitive data (host ip's etc..) and they would rather these be totally separate.


"also, tbh the state/property_change types seem to be identical to many of the current notifications that are emitted this seems like rather than duplicating functionality, this could all be consumed by ceilometer[1]/existing notification consumers and the visible results be configured through policies."

I think this *could* be done (in similar way to how yagi operates), provide a way to convert RPC notifications into user-events but as I have said before not everyone will like that idea.

I'll update the spec soon to use Zaqar and see what people think of that.'}, {'account_id': 6537, 'date': '2015-06-10 03:33:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

oslo.messaging has the ability to classify notifications/events[1]. maybe it makes sense to publish user events on a specific level (maybe a new 'user' level) and its consumers can control its access.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.messaging/blob/master/oslo_messaging/notify/notifier.py#L188-L292"}, {'account_id': 6159, 'date': '2015-06-10 08:22:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

I've left some comments in-line, mostly related to the proposal of adding a new service (I'm a bit biased, I know). But really, I think we don't need a new service for this. It'll just split efforts and confuse the community further.

Please, lets talk about this better and see what can be done that won't require yet another notifications service."}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2016-03-11 19:25:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Angus, this spec appears to be stale. Are you interested in reviving it or finding someone interested in reviving it. Afterwards we can have it in the cross-project meeting for a wider audience discussion https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Meetings/CrossProjectMeeting ... otherwise I'll be proposing to the TC to abandon this spec. Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 17860, 'date': '2016-09-02 12:16:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2021-06-18 16:28:04.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This repo is retiring https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-specs/+/796963'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-17 17:07:04.000000000', 'message': 'Correct the tox option for skipping sdist generation

The tox option to skip source distribution building is skipsdist,
but this seems to be often misspelled skipdist instead, which gets
silently ignored and so does not take effect. Correct it
everywhere, in hopes that new projects will finally stop copying
this mistake around.

See https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-skipsdist
and https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/issues/1388 for details.

Change-Id: I8bb1a9a9d510be050306a407e31d8dffb1e93da8
'}]
commit_message:
Correct the tox option for skipping sdist generation

The tox option to skip source distribution building is skipsdist,
but this seems to be often misspelled skipdist instead, which gets
silently ignored and so does not take effect. Correct it
everywhere, in hopes that new projects will finally stop copying
this mistake around.

See https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-skipsdist
and https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/issues/1388 for details.

Change-Id: I8bb1a9a9d510be050306a407e31d8dffb1e93da8

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-04-24 11:58:58.000000000', 'message': 'Align nova microversion declaration

The data in this repo is normalized, not a direct copy of the data
emitted by the project. While it is true that Nova returns 'version' and
not 'max_version', the intent is for the structures here to match the
API-WG spec. (Thus, keystone lists "CURRENT" not "stable", for instance)

Change-Id: I37baedf3e199f49e4574956af13ce2ff48ca7f82
'}]
commit_message:
Align nova microversion declaration

The data in this repo is normalized, not a direct copy of the data
emitted by the project. While it is true that Nova returns 'version' and
not 'max_version', the intent is for the structures here to match the
API-WG spec. (Thus, keystone lists "CURRENT" not "stable", for instance)

Change-Id: I37baedf3e199f49e4574956af13ce2ff48ca7f82

commit_message:
Update min tox version to 2.0

The commands used by constraints need at least tox 2.0.  Update to
reflect reality, which should help with local running of constraints
targets.

Change-Id: I7d79a65e22c5d93561c87aa439673c303825f890

'}, {'created': '2021-05-04 09:32:45.000000000', 'message': "setup.cfg: Replace dashes with underscores

Setuptools v54.1.0 introduces a warning that the use of dash-separated

Get ahead of the issue by replacing the dashes with underscores. Without

commit_message:
setup.cfg: Replace dashes with underscores

Setuptools v54.1.0 introduces a warning that the use of dash-separated
options in 'setup.cfg' will not be supported in a future version [1].
Get ahead of the issue by replacing the dashes with underscores. Without
this, we see 'UserWarning' messages like the following on new enough
versions of setuptools:

  UserWarning: Usage of dash-separated 'description-file' will not be
  supported in future versions. Please use the underscore name
  'description_file' instead

[1] https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/commit/a2e9ae4cb

Change-Id: Id3130f4f98cf934f67caa78573a501aa978cdebf

commit_message:
Handle OPERATION_FAILED error during detach

While libvirt 4.1 started to use DEVICE_MISSING for most of the cases
there is still one[1] using OPERATION_FAILED when the device is missing
during detach. So nova needs to handle that properly.

Revert this when libvirt merges[1] and nova bumps the min version over
to that release.

[1] https://listman.redhat.com/archives/libvir-list/2021-June/msg00337.html

Change-Id: Ibc967be291853e23027d9b8210ece572adcc80c9
Closes-Bug: #1931716

commit_message:
Use py3 as the default runtime for tox

Moving on py3 as the default runtime for tox to avoid to update this at each new cycle.

Wallaby support officially the following runtimes [1]:
- Python 3.6
- Python 3.7

During Victoria Python 3.7 was used as the default runtime [2] however this version isn't longer officially supported.

Change-Id: Ia71e235ec791fdd73c310213008f9113d680b8ea

[{'created': '2020-06-10 14:28:29.000000000', 'message': "Switch to newer openstackdocstheme and reno versions

Switch to openstackdocstheme 2.2.1 and reno 3.1.0 versions. Using
these versions will allow especially:
* Linking from HTML to PDF document
* Allow parallel building of documents
* Fix some rendering problems

Update Sphinx version as well.

Disable openstackdocs_auto_version to not auto-version the documents.

Disable openstackdocs_auto_name to use 'project' variable as name.

Change pygments_style to 'native' since old theme version always used
'native' and the theme now respects the setting and using 'sphinx' can
lead to some strange rendering.

Remove docs requirements from lower-constraints, they are not needed
during install or test but only for docs building.

openstackdocstheme renames some variables, so follow the renames
before the next release removes them. A couple of variables are also
not needed anymore, remove them.

See also
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-May/014971.html

Cleanup requirements, tox.ini, setup.py for Python3.

commit_message:
Switch to newer openstackdocstheme and reno versions

Switch to openstackdocstheme 2.2.1 and reno 3.1.0 versions. Using
these versions will allow especially:
* Linking from HTML to PDF document
* Allow parallel building of documents
* Fix some rendering problems

Update Sphinx version as well.

Disable openstackdocs_auto_version to not auto-version the documents.

Disable openstackdocs_auto_name to use 'project' variable as name.

Change pygments_style to 'native' since old theme version always used
'native' and the theme now respects the setting and using 'sphinx' can
lead to some strange rendering.

Remove docs requirements from lower-constraints, they are not needed
during install or test but only for docs building.

openstackdocstheme renames some variables, so follow the renames
before the next release removes them. A couple of variables are also
not needed anymore, remove them.

See also
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-May/014971.html

Cleanup requirements, tox.ini, setup.py for Python3.
Fix build problems.

Change-Id: If53a2edbb8b351b9dea8ba49bb35145a34714159

Sync sphinx dependency with global requirements. It caps python 2 since

subject: Add ops:ha tag
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 330, 'name': 'John Dickinson', 'email': 'me@not.mn', 'username': 'notmyname'}, {'_account_id': 612, 'name': 'Tom Fifield', 'email': 'tom@openstack.org', 'username': 'fifieldt'}, {'_account_id': 964, 'name': 'Anne Gentle', 'email': 'annegentle@justwriteclick.com', 'username': 'annegentle'}, {'_account_id': 4625, 'name': 'Jonathan Proulx', 'email': 'jon@jonproulx.com', 'username': 'jproulx'}, {'_account_id': 9060, 'name': 'Mike Dorman', 'email': 'dorm@dorm.org', 'username': 'gd-mdorman'}, {'_account_id': 9444, 'name': 'gustavo panizzo', 'email': 'gfa@zumbi.com.ar', 'username': 'gfa'}, {'_account_id': 10348, 'name': 'Maish Saidel-Keesing', 'email': 'maishsk@gmail.com', 'username': 'maishsk'}, {'_account_id': 12651, 'name': 'Shamail Tahir', 'email': 'ItzShamail@gmail.com', 'username': 'shamail'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 10348, 'date': '2015-07-09 14:36:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10348, 'date': '2015-07-09 14:37:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-07-09 14:38:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- noop http://logs.openstack.org/28/200128/1/check/noop/dc0e29a/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 10348, 'date': '2015-07-10 08:42:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Workflow'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2015-07-13 14:39:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10348, 'date': '2015-07-13 19:47:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Thanks John for the correction.'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2015-07-13 20:20:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10348, 'date': '2015-07-13 20:43:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Anne when you refer to the 'identity requirement' - are you referring to Keystone? If so this is not part of this tag. I do not think that this tag is here to state which components rely *on each other* - but rather if they can be deployed in a HA manner - and if they have external dependencies (such as DB / MQ) then they should be noted."}, {'account_id': 4625, 'date': '2015-07-13 20:46:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I don't think specific caveats are required for external HA systems where they are documented (even by reference) in the HA Guide.

For example Database (usually MySQL) and Queue (usually Rabbit) are dependancies of many base projects. There's relatively well worn paths to making these HA so I don't think they need extra warning here."}, {'account_id': 14496, 'date': '2015-07-13 20:54:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I have some concerns about this. 

First of all, we should be more explicit about what it means to be highly available. For example, anything *could* be made highly available by (for example) deploying in an environment which supports that at the infrastructure level (e.g. VMware Live Migration + DRS), but that doesn't mean that the application itself exhibits any 'highly available' characteristics.

Secondly, I think there is value in differentiating between the different HA models we have available to us. For example, some services can be scaled or made highly available by just hanging more instances of of a message broker or database. Some services require more care and feeding or can only exist in an active/passive configuration.

As things are now I feel like a single HA label doesn't provide the right nuance.

My personal opinion is that nothing which doesn't support scale-out active / active HA at the application level shouldn't be considered to be HA at all."}, {'account_id': 10348, 'date': '2015-07-13 20:55:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks Jonathan - essentially I agree. I do think that this should apply for all those services that rely on MySQL and RabbitMQ. 
I do think though that the caveat that is there for Mongo *specifically* must remain there - since this is not covered anywhere in the documentation, and it never has.'}, {'account_id': 10348, 'date': '2015-07-13 21:06:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks Richard. 
VMware DRS and vMotion never has and never will provide application level redundancy.
Going into a philosophical debate of what is HA (Active/Active or Active Standby) is not the purpose. I do agree with you that the rationale can be tweaked a bit further to expand - exactly what HA means (in this specific tag's context)
Regarding the differentiation of which HA model is in use - is a great point - but I think that could better be part of another tag - for example ops:service-scalable (yes/no) 
My intent is to start out somewhere - and re-iterate and adapt as needed.
Very constructive feedback - please keep it coming!"}, {'account_id': 9060, 'date': '2015-07-13 22:25:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)

I'm primarily an operator.  Comments/questions inline."}, {'account_id': 9444, 'date': '2015-07-14 02:02:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

as an ops, -1. i don't think this is useful in current form. 

as Richard said we should clarify what HA means, everything can be HA if underline infrastructure makes it (vmware or pacemaker for example). i think only *components* which are able to be scaled horizontally should  bear the HA tag.

and only components, not the whole nova or neutron or glance project, components like glance-api, neutron-l3-agent, etc"}, {'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2015-07-14 08:20:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

I agree with Gustavo, we need to go from project level to service level if we want to have meaningful information on HA level support.'}, {'account_id': 10348, 'date': '2015-07-14 11:51:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(4 comments)

Thanks for all the feedback.
Regarding the granularity. Having it as a project level is problematic, I agree. 

Would perhaps having these as child tags help?
for example 
ops:ha:cinder:scheduler - available - because it is documented and possible
ops:ha:cinder:volume - not available. 

This does give more granularity, and the requirement that ops:ha:cinder is available - is that all it's children are also available. 

The only concern I have here is that the could be getting too much into detail - and if this information is actually something that Operator would find useful and want.

Thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2015-07-14 12:32:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)

From my perspective simple HA or not-HA tag for project doesn't provide valuable information for operator. Projects have different issues with different services. I would prefer not to add the tag if it will be only assigned to projects.

Maybe something like that would be better:
1. Project is marked with HA tag if all *required* services can be deployed in HA fashion. Information about each service is in tag metadata (like caveats in current proposition).
2. Project is marked as non-HA if there's at least one service essential for the project to run that has problems with achieving HA."}, {'account_id': 9060, 'date': '2015-07-14 15:46:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

I like Michal's approach here."}, {'account_id': 612, 'date': '2015-07-15 03:13:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think Michal has it with "1. Project is marked with HA tag if all *required* services can be deployed in HA fashion.  2. Project is marked as non-HA if there's at least one service essential for the project to run that has problems with achieving HA."

However, I don't think we can honestly achieve "Information about *each* service ... in tag metadata." (emphasis added).


This sounds like we'd have to prepare an exhaustive matrix of the status of every single service in every single project which is a) unmaintainable given our current resources, and b) not useful in the #1 case where every service can be deployed HA :)


What I think is a reasonable compromise is to add a caveat where there's some random service that is majorly different to the others, or particularly for the #2 case - give some little bit of info about what the deal is as to why a project is non-HA.'}, {'account_id': 10348, 'date': '2015-07-15 08:44:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I agree with you Tom. Storing this information for each and every service has far too much overhead and I am not even sure how to accomplish this.

So can we agree that a project will be tagged as Highly Available if the following criteria are met:

1. *All* essential services required (*and are provided*) by that project can be deployed in redundant manner
[MySQL is an essential service for most OpenStack projects - but it not developed by OpenStack - so that is why I emphasized 'provided by']

2. Documentation is in place in *docs.openstack.org* on how this can be accomplished.


The questions that jump at me - is what is considered essential? Can that be defined?"}, {'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2015-07-15 10:32:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Okay, I agree with Tom and Maish. Fact if service can be considered essential is easy to define - for example you can run Nova without nova-network (Neutron can replace it), but you cannot run Nova without nova-conductor. That's it I think."}, {'account_id': 12651, 'date': '2016-03-31 16:41:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 12651, 'date': '2016-03-31 16:43:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I updated the tag description to incorporate feedback, however I did not update any content in the kilo tag itself because:

A) I believe we need to revisit this once we have agreed on the tag description and classifications.
B) We should discuss how to address sub-components data when creating the tag for each release.

I propose that we redefine the implementation of the tag at our meeting in Austin and then build the tags for Liberty and Mitaka (and disregard Kilo at this point).'}, {'account_id': 12651, 'date': '2016-03-31 16:44:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Published edit on patch set 2'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-03-31 16:55:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- noop http://logs.openstack.org/28/200128/3/check/noop/c732792/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2016-05-23 18:28:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-10-21 21:20:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- noop http://logs.openstack.org/28/200128/3/check/noop/3011ed3/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2021-06-18 16:24:09.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This repo is retiring https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ops-tags-team/+/796968'}]

the redundancy capabilities of the projects in OpenStack.

commit_message:
Update WG collection scripts for AUC

This change includes an update get_meeting_data script that includes
collecting data for additional working groups.  Get_active_wg_members
has also been updated to show eligible WG members from the current
release cycle.

subject: Modify AskOpenStackMods Script for AUC Requirements
messages:
[{'account_id': 12651, 'date': '2016-07-14 05:40:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-07-14 05:40:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- noop http://logs.openstack.org/55/341955/1/check/noop/bf8150c/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 12651, 'date': '2016-07-14 05:41:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-07-14 05:41:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- noop http://logs.openstack.org/55/341955/2/check/noop/fdbb771/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 12651, 'date': '2016-07-14 05:42:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-07-14 05:42:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- noop http://logs.openstack.org/55/341955/3/check/noop/e64f4eb/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 612, 'date': '2016-07-15 05:23:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

hi! can you talk more about using a static date rather than a sliding window.'}, {'account_id': 12651, 'date': '2016-07-15 06:24:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

The date range is dynamic but the starting point is now set to the date of the last OpenStack release statically.  This will ensure that the data collected only includes the current release cycle.  The old version used 180 days as the sliding window and that could cross release boundaries (e.g. 180 ago from today we were still in the Mitaka cycle).  

The last_release_date will need to be updated after each release but, with this one minor change, the script will be able to accurately determine how many days have passed since the last release and return only the users who were "last seen online" in the current cycle.'}, {'account_id': 612, 'date': '2016-07-19 02:48:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Thanks Shamail.

So the AUC WG decided that it cares about participation in release cycles over participation within date-based timeframes?

I can see this making sense for deliverables that are tied to the release cycle, but this deliverable in particular is not. As a result, the change might exclude people who would otherwise qualify.

Something else to tie into the thinking is: is the AUC list generated for tasks outside the time close to release cycle boundaries? For example, when does voting happen?'}, {'account_id': 12651, 'date': '2016-08-02 18:48:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hi Tom,  we discussed this at the last AUC meeting (although we had light attendance)... we are considering keeping this to "last seen" within the current cycle for now.  I can bring it up at the next meeting if you want to wait for more data...

Excerpt from meeting:
19:24:31 <shamail> Tom posted a comment on a change request for the AskOpenStackMods team script
19:24:32 <shamail> #link https://review.openstack.org/#/c/341955/
19:25:00 <shamail> His comment: I can see this making sense for deliverables that are tied to the release cycle, but this deliverable in particular is not. As a result, the change might exclude people who would otherwise qualify.
19:25:00 <shamail> Something else to tie into the thinking is: is the AUC list generated for tasks outside the time close to release cycle boundaries? For example, when does voting happen?
19:25:37 <shamail> I can reply but wanted to validate my response with you...
19:25:49 <MeganR> ok
19:27:08 <shamail> I think we decided that for Ask OpenStack Mods we wanted to tie them with the same time window as others (e.g. release cycle) so that we can ensure that only active participants are included.  The concern is that a WG member has to be active each cycle to recieve credit even though some of their deliverables (e.g. eBooks, etc) might have a longer life (similar to Ask OpenStack Mods)
19:27:31 <MeganR> I agree
19:27:39 <shamail> In general, we choose to focus on active as a criteria to make all contribution types as equal as possible
19:27:42 <shamail> (effort wise)
19:28:13 <MeganR> with the first iteration though, we are trying to establish a baseline, who is active, and then will tie in a date range on the same timeframe as ATC?
19:28:26 <shamail> The second part we addressed as wellâ¦ which is generally we will do AUC collection at feature-freeze or RC1â¦ we would know track chairs by then.
19:28:49 <shamail> MeganR: +1 makes sense....
19:28:59 <shamail> So should first revision go back more than 180?
19:29:06 <shamail> To reward past contributors?
19:29:51 <MeganR> I don't think so, we are trying to focus on current participation and the current release'}, {'account_id': 612, 'date': '2016-08-03 03:25:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Thanks Shamail.

I guess the assumption that I am challenging is that AUC is "calculated" once per cycle, rather than continually.

For example, if I make a contribution in April, when does my AUC period expire? 

Is it 6 months from that day? 1 month; when the new release cycle starts? 7 months; at the end of the next release cycle?'}, {'account_id': 612, 'date': '2016-08-03 03:35:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

s/continually/more often than once :)'}, {'account_id': 12651, 'date': '2016-08-03 15:49:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

@Tom:  The current thought process is that we will capture the list of AUCs at R-5 (milestone-3 and feature freeze) for the current release cycle.  This would, for example, be Aug 29th - Sept. 2nd for the Newton cycle.  The data used for building the list would be based on contribution activities from the date of the last release to milestone-3 of the current release.  The AUC designation would be valid for the entirety of the next cycle (so milestone-3 to Ocata release).   

This does leave a gap since this model would not identify people who contribute between milestone-3 and the upcoming Summit (so Sept - End of Oct. 2016 currently).  One way of addressing this might be to leverage data from milestone-3 to milestone-3 vs. previous release date to milestone-3.  Thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 612, 'date': '2016-08-03 17:20:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

NB: late night incoherence warning!


OK, so the theoretical April contribution would not count (missed the cut-off). While a May contribution would last 12 months (two full cycles) :)

This seems ... problematic?


Correct me if I'm wrong here, but it seems much of the thinking is around getting an AUC designation on summit badges? If so, I'd advise trying to think more broadly, but to complete this one first: did you know that ATC discount codes are sent out at multiple points throughout the cycle? Part of the reasoning behind that is to encourage those qualifying to register early so we have the best possible idea of numbers as early as we can.

The current plan of calculating AUC status once (per cycle) doesn't support this


On to those other ideas. How about User Committee Voting. That might happen in January, for instance. Assuming AUC members are qualified to vote, when is their eligibility determined? From the last list made in milestone 3 of whatever release cycle was previously done?

To further that idea. ATC has a handy script at https://github.com/openstack/election/blob/master/tools/check-candidacy.py that allows the verification that someone is eligible to stand for election. It queries gerrit and looks for contributions over the time period. How does that kind of script work for AUC candidates standing for the UC election?


More outlandish: what about if the foundation somehow falls upon a ton of stickers and some stamps/envelopes and want to mail AUC recipients some "tomorrow". How does generating that list work, and who qualifies on that particular random date :)



Anyway, it's late and none of this may make any sense, but I hope that at least one of these questions is helpful for thinking about the time ranges and use of the data! I hope to be more coherent in the morning :)'}, {'account_id': 12651, 'date': '2016-08-03 21:27:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Great points!  I get the need for compiling the list more often now.  The AUC designation would not last for 12 months but it would be slightly over 1 release cycle.  I will follow up tomorrow with a more detailed reply to your post but I am mainly in agreement and will bring up these points at the next AUC meeting as well.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-02-14 15:23:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified-1

Merge Failed.

This change or one of its cross-repo dependencies was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of its repository. Please rebase the change and upload a new patchset.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2017-12-18 04:07:19.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Jenkins with the following votes:

* Verified-1 by Jenkins (3)
'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2021-06-18 16:22:58.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This repo is retiring https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/uc-recognition/+/796969'}]

[{'created': '2021-05-14 06:19:01.000000000', 'message': "setup.cfg: Replace dashes with underscores

Setuptools v54.1.0 introduces a warning that the use of dash-separated
options in 'setup.cfg' will not be supported in a future version [1].
Get ahead of the issue by replacing the dashes with underscores. Without
this, we see 'UserWarning' messages like the following on new enough
versions of setuptools:

  UserWarning: Usage of dash-separated 'description-file' will not be
  supported in future versions. Please use the underscore name
  'description_file' instead

[1] https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/commit/a2e9ae4cb

Change-Id: I478d640e3f5473ef7f694b59a0b2500cf680202e
"}]
commit_message:
setup.cfg: Replace dashes with underscores

Setuptools v54.1.0 introduces a warning that the use of dash-separated
options in 'setup.cfg' will not be supported in a future version [1].
Get ahead of the issue by replacing the dashes with underscores. Without
this, we see 'UserWarning' messages like the following on new enough
versions of setuptools:

  UserWarning: Usage of dash-separated 'description-file' will not be
  supported in future versions. Please use the underscore name
  'description_file' instead

[1] https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/commit/a2e9ae4cb

Change-Id: I478d640e3f5473ef7f694b59a0b2500cf680202e

messages:
[{'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2021-06-09 08:39:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2021-06-14 18:40:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2021-06-15 14:15:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

this works now'}, {'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2021-06-15 14:51:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

As discussed on IRC, it only works because C8S (wrongly) uses C8L's AV repo, to which libvirt 7.0.0 was added recently. With libvirt 7.0.0 the tests still pass despites the "unknown feature" error being logged, not sure why.

Anyway, libvirt 7.4.0 will get pulled soon when C8S AV starts being used.'}, {'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2021-06-18 05:36:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2021-06-18 07:45:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Revert "libvirt: pin edk2-ovmf"

The "internal error: unknown feature amd-sev-es" error in libvirt seen
with the edk2-ovmf package is fixed by a commit in libvirt 7.4.0 [0] to
avoid erroring out on unknown QEMU firmware features.

CentOS Stream 8 was wrongly using the CentOS 8 advanced-virtualization
repository [1] instead of the CentOS Stream 8 one [2]. This is fixed by
centos-release-advanced-virtualization-1.0-3 [3], which should bring
libvirt-7.4.0-1 into our nova-libvirt image.

This reverts commit 1a2c33512b6c4bdcdbf7d7bb08e791fb53e4f063.

[0] https://github.com/libvirt/libvirt/commit/61d95a1073833ec4323c1ef28e71e913c55aa7b9
[1] http://mirror.centos.org/centos/8/virt/x86_64/advanced-virtualization/
[2] http://mirror.centos.org/centos/8-stream/virt/x86_64/advancedvirt-common/
[3] https://koji.mbox.centos.org/koji/buildinfo?buildID=18004

Change-Id: I1f58262109dd27a4c4ee9b60d87010170b5ea7bb
(cherry picked from commit 8ec8ef3d8a1a852187bbaf4b592f0739e2796abd)

Now it uses just one.

commit_message:
get_formatted_data optimization

The property previously used multiple loops and nested
conditions for making a dictionary copy with formatted keys.

Now it uses just one.
Could be reduced further assuming substitution of 'Id' for 'ID'.

Signed-off-by: Jiri Podivin <jpodivin@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I6ef708b6d39ac56354881b89421ff4c0771c6ab5

commit_message:
overcloud deploy - provision networks

When the network file provided as input to the overcloud
deploy command is a network-v2 format file. Provision
networks and include the deployed network environment
file in user environments.

Change-Id: I20da47f8dfbf48f6ee46e60a07c00482545cb444
(cherry picked from commit 2b2e52c88235ac49a0c7fb76eeb40a0989d0a6ed)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-01 14:39:02.000000000', 'message': 'Compute TSX validation

RHEL-8.3 kernel disabled the Intel TSX (Transactional
Synchronization Extensions) feature by default as a preemptive
security measure, but it breaks live migration from RHEL-7.9
(or even RHEL-8.1 or RHEL-8.2) to RHEL-8.3.

Operators are expected to explicitly define the TSX flag in
their KernelArgs for the compute role to prevent live-migration
issues during the upgrade process.

Co-Authored-By: Martin Schuppert <mschuppert@redhat.com>
Related: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/1923165
Closes-Bug: #1916758
Change-Id: Icfcfb1c07bbfbe05d27d67187d941c0c34fad2b2
(cherry picked from commit 46567181662ac6fe3ef5659ebc4ff90d10f0884b)

commit_message:
Compute TSX validation

RHEL-8.3 kernel disabled the Intel TSX (Transactional
Synchronization Extensions) feature by default as a preemptive
security measure, but it breaks live migration from RHEL-7.9
(or even RHEL-8.1 or RHEL-8.2) to RHEL-8.3.

Operators are expected to explicitly define the TSX flag in
their KernelArgs for the compute role to prevent live-migration
issues during the upgrade process.

This also impacts upstream CentOS systems.

Co-Authored-By: Martin Schuppert <mschuppert@redhat.com>
Related: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/1923165
Closes-Bug: #1916758
Change-Id: Icfcfb1c07bbfbe05d27d67187d941c0c34fad2b2
(cherry picked from commit ede25c3e36a751daf68ce151521b371bb25f50dc)

Change-Id: I6d1686ab79647acfc086f21864bde14c8a1a1a49
'}, {'created': '2021-04-28 15:30:43.000000000', 'message': 'DNM Change task ordering to perform smooth upgrades

Change-Id: I6d1686ab79647acfc086f21864bde14c8a1a1a49
'}, {'created': '2021-04-28 17:00:45.000000000', 'message': 'Change task ordering to perform smooth upgrades

Currently we symlink /etc/neutron to empty directory at pre-stage,
and filling it with config only during post_install. This means,
that policies and rootwrap filters are not working properly until
playbook execution finish. Additionally, we replace sudoers file
with new path in it, which makes current operations impossible for
the service, since rootwrap can not gain sudo privileges.

With this change we move symlinking and rootwrap steps to handlers,
which means that we will do replace configs while service is stopped.

During post_install we place all of the configs inside the venv,
which is versioned at the moment.

This way we minimise downtime of the service while performing upgrades

Change-Id: I6d1686ab79647acfc086f21864bde14c8a1a1a49

commit_message:
Change task ordering to perform smooth upgrades

Currently we symlink /etc/neutron to empty directory at pre-stage,
and filling it with config only during post_install. This means,
that policies and rootwrap filters are not working properly until
playbook execution finish. Additionally, we replace sudoers file
with new path in it, which makes current operations impossible for
the service, since rootwrap can not gain sudo privileges.

With this change we move symlinking and rootwrap steps to handlers,
which means that we will do replace configs while service is stopped.

During post_install we place all of the configs inside the venv,
which is versioned at the moment.

This way we minimise downtime of the service while performing upgrades

Change-Id: I6d1686ab79647acfc086f21864bde14c8a1a1a49

commit_message:
Add task to remove particular actors from leapp

This patch adds task to remove actors that are in conflict with RHOSP.
This patch also removes persistentnetnamesdisable from leapp in case of
undercloud is run from virtual machine.

Change-Id: I1d8619c8420144a35f9d74a7d820419d86fa101d

subject: Correct the tox option for skipping sdist generation
messages: [{'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2021-06-17 17:09:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17685, 'date': '2021-06-18 10:30:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2\n\nOh, nice catch!'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2021-06-18 15:03:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-17 17:09:09.000000000', 'message': 'Correct the tox option for skipping sdist generation

The tox option to skip source distribution building is skipsdist,
but this seems to be often misspelled skipdist instead, which gets
silently ignored and so does not take effect. Correct it
everywhere, in hopes that new projects will finally stop copying
this mistake around.

See https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-skipsdist
and https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/issues/1388 for details.

Change-Id: I56bd83c4d70e751df6576a38111a5fa5ef656dac
'}]
commit_message:
Correct the tox option for skipping sdist generation

The tox option to skip source distribution building is skipsdist,
but this seems to be often misspelled skipdist instead, which gets
silently ignored and so does not take effect. Correct it
everywhere, in hopes that new projects will finally stop copying
this mistake around.

See https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#conf-skipsdist
and https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/issues/1388 for details.

Change-Id: I56bd83c4d70e751df6576a38111a5fa5ef656dac
